sentence: Charles Allan Rich (December 14, 1932 – July 25, 1995) was an American country music singer, songwriter, and musician.

Charles Allan Rich (December 14, 1932 – July 25, 1995) was an American country music singer, songwriter, and musician.
Charles Allan Rich (December 14, 1932 – July 25, 1995) was an American country music singer, songwriter, and musician.

He is perhaps best remembered for a pair of 1973 hits, "Behind Closed Doors" and "The Most Beautiful Girl, topped the U.S. country singles charts, as well as the Billboard Hot 100 pop singles charts and earned him two Grammy Awards.

==== CMA awards 1975 ====
Rich's destructive personal behavior famously culminated at the CMA awards ceremony for 1975, when he presented the award for Entertainer of the Year, while visibly intoxicated.

section: == Career == | === Decline in activity and semiretirement ===

sentence: Tom Waits, who was an opening act for Rich in the 1970s, mentions him in the song "Putnam County" from his album Nighthawks at the Diner with the lyric: "The radio's spitting out Charlie Rich...
section: == Career == | === Decline in activity and semiretirement ===

sentence: Rich died in his sleep on July 25, 1995, in a Hammond, Louisiana motel, at age 62.
Rich died in his sleep on July 25, 1995, in a Hammond, Louisiana motel, at age 62.
He was buried in the Memorial Park Cemetery in Memphis, Tennessee.Rich was survived by his wife of 43 years, Margaret, two sons, two daughters and three grandchildren.

Margaret Rich died in Germantown, Tennessee, on July 22, 2010, and was buried alongside her husband.
